thread.title: Concerns after white spot found in Moreton Bay's wild prawns - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Concerns after white spot found in Moreton Bay's wild prawns - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Stephanie Smail
title: Concerns after white spot found in Moreton Bay's wild prawns - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Logan Central 4114 
White spot disease has been detected in more than 100 wild prawns south of Brisbane, sparking fears about the prawn farm industry's recovery. 
The virus has destroyed $25 million worth of farmed prawn stocks on the Logan River since it was first detected in November. 
A small number of wild prawns also tested positive at the time but authorities said the disease was not established among those populations. 
But today, it was announced that more than 100 wild prawns had now tested positive, just south of the river mouth, in Moreton Bay. 
"This is the first time we've found it in this area," Jim Thompson from Biosecurity Queensland said. 
"It's easy to jump to the conclusion that it's moved to that area, but it might have started there. 
"It's very hard to detect in the wild. 
"We need more large numbers of samples in this area and probably further afield now to make sure that we know the extent of the spread of the virus." Video: Prawns jump from the water as they attempt to escape chlorine being poured into their pond to kill them. (ABC News) 
Dr Thompson said if the river system was contaminated it could make it harder for farms to recover. 
"If it's widespread in the wild then clearly that makes it difficult to manage into the future," he said. 
"If you can't be certain of how clean the water that comes into these properties is then you have some real concerns about managing it." 
But he said Biosecurity Queensland would not jump to conclusions until more testing was done, including an investigation into whether the prawns came from a nearby farm. 
He said more frequent testing would be rolled out in Moreton Bay, the Pine River and the Brisbane River to check if other wild prawns were infected. 
The area accounts for about one-third of Australia's $90-million farmed prawn industry.
